metadata.case_name: Owners of lands at Ranoli v. State of Gujarat and Company

facts.text: Appellants are owners of lands situate at Ranoli, District Baroda, either adjacent to and between the Company's lands and the railway lines or enclaves surrounded by lands belonging to the 3rd respondent Company which owns about 140 acres in the same village.

On July 22, 1961 the State Government issued a notification under sec. 4 of the Land Acquisition Act stating that the appellants' lands were or were likely to be needed for a public purpose, viz., for a fertilizer factory.
Notification dated July 22, 1961 was withdrawn on September 11, 1961 as the lands were stated to be unsuitable for such a factory.

On September 12, 1961 the Government issued a fresh notification under sec. 4 in respect of the same lands for the purpose of the 3rd respondent Company. Some appellants filed writ petitions challenging its validity.

This Court delivered its decision in the first Arora Case. To get over difficulties arising from that decision, first an Ordinance and then the Amendment Act XXXI of 1962 were passed, brought into force from July 20, 1962 with retrospective effect.
Central Government made Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules under sec. 55 of the Act, brought into force from June 22, 1963.
On July 24, 1963 the State Government withdrew the notification dated September 12, 1961, whereupon the writ petitions challenging it were withdrawn.
D.K. Master, Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda, started an inquiry under Rule 4 of the said Rules.
Master worked as Special L.A. officer at Baroda from December 6, 1961 to April 29, 1965. On February 11, 1963 appointed to officiate as Special Land Acquisition Officer, Baroda.

On October 1, 1963 Government wrote letter to Master forwarding Company's application dated September 11, 1963 requesting acquisition, directing him to hold inquiry under Rules and make report, stating he was being authorised separately to perform functions of Collector.
On October 1, 1963 Government issued notification under sec. 3(c) authorising Master to perform functions of Collector within Baroda District.

On October 11, 1963 Government issued another notification superseding October 1 notification, authorising all Special Land Acquisition Officers in the State to perform functions of Collector under the Act within their jurisdiction.
On October 10, 1963 Master addressed letter to Company to supply information for inquiry under Rule 4.
On October 22, 1963 Master issued notices to 27 owners, 10 appeared, statements recorded on October 31, 1963.
State Government appointed a Land Acquisition Committee before issuing sec. 4 notification as required by Rules.
On August 28, 1964 State Government issued notification under sec. 4 stating appellants' lands needed or likely needed for establishment of factory of 3rd respondent Company.
Appellants filed objections in inquiry under sec. 5A, but rejected.

On October 18, 1965 State Government issued sec. 6 notification declaring lands needed for factory of 3rd respondent Company, which was taking steps for manufacture of optical bleaching agents, intermediate dye-stuffs etc., stated as public purpose.
Appellants filed writ petitions in Gujarat High Court challenging notifications dated August 28, 1964 and October 18, 1965. High Court dismissed them on October 15, 1966.

Out of Company's 140 acres: 48 acres ravine lands unfit for factory sites, to be used for housing 700 workmen and amenities; 40 acres used for factories, warehouses, godowns; balance 60 acres not compact, contain small pockets of appellants' lands.

Company's lands divided by Nal which if filled would block access to appellants' lands; enclaves necessary; portion needed for approach road to railway siding; some land to be kept open to avoid noxious fumes.
Master's inquiry on whether Company trying to acquire excessive land.
Appellants' lands near existing goods platform, suitable for railway siding.
Some appellants' lands used for manufacture of sagol.

legal_issues.text: Whether the inquiry under Rule 4 of the Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules and the consequent report by Master were invalid, therefore no valid report under Rule 4 read with section 40, no notification under s.4 or sec.6 could be validly issued.

Whether sec.6 notification issued without complying with Part VII of the Act and without valid consent of State Government as required by sec.39, therefore no notification under sec.4 or sec.6 could be lawfully issued.
Whether the acquisition was made mala fide and without application of mind to the relevant facts.
Whether the acquisition involved any public purpose.
Whether the State Government was bound to give opportunity of being heard to appellants before taking decision under sec.5A, particularly when Master's report was against acquisition.

petitioner_arguments.text: Master was only Special L.A. officer, not the Collector within meaning of Rule 4; inquiry and report invalid; no direction to make report; notification Oct 11,1963 merely authorised, not specially appointed as per sec.3(c).
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules Rule 4; Land Acquisition Act sec.3(c)

petitioner_arguments.text: Sec.6 notification issued without complying with Part VII and valid consent under sec.39.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act secs.39, Part VII

petitioner_arguments.text: Acquisition mala fide and without application of mind; Company has sufficient land (140 acres), acquisition to get neighbouring lands without using own; repeated notifications since 1962 show mala fides; Master's opinion adverse.
No public purpose as lands already used for one public purpose (manufacture of sagol), cannot substitute another.
Even if sec.5A inquiry administrative, entitled to be heard before Government forms satisfaction for sec.6, especially with adverse Master's report.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act sec.5A; natural justice

petitioner_arguments.text: Inquiry under Rule 4 is quasi-judicial, no opportunity given to owners.
Inquiry under Rule 4 must be after sec.4 notification, not before.

respondent_arguments.text: Master duly authorised under sec.3(c) notifications to perform Collector's functions; inquiry valid; notices issued to owners, statements recorded.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Land Acquisition Act sec.3(c); General Clauses Act secs.15,20

respondent_arguments.text: Company needs lands to make compact block; ravine lands for housing/amenities; 40 acres already used; 60 acres fragmented by pockets/enclaves/Nal; needed for railway siding near goods platform, open space for health.
Government applied mind based on Master's report and sec.5A report; cancellation of first notification shows independent application; not bound by Master's adverse opinion.

court_reasoning.text: Master specially appointed via notifications to perform Collector's functions under sec.3(c); 'specially appointed' means for specific purpose, not individual vs general; General Clauses Act applies; authorisation = appointment in context.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Word 'specially' qualifies appointment for Act's functions, not person; notifications validly appoint by office.

court_reasoning.text: Inquiry under Rule 4 before sec.4 valid; intended for tentative conclusion before notification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in Rule 4 requires post-sec.4 inquiry.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 4 inquiry not quasi-judicial for owners (only hears Company), but Master gave opportunity anyway.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Owners heard via notices and statements recorded.

court_reasoning.text: Valid consent under Part VII; compliance with Rules, sec.40; notifications valid.
No mala fides; vague allegations; Company explained land use; Government considered reports; prior withdrawal shows application of mind, no collusion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Repeated notifications due to legal changes, not mala fides; Master's independence noted.

court_reasoning.text: Public purpose exists; similar argument rejected in Somawanti's Case.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature empowers change of public purpose.

court_reasoning.text: Sec.5A provides hearing; record including objections goes to Government for satisfaction; no second opportunity required before sec.6.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellants heard under sec.5A; Government had full record.

holdings.text: Master validly authorised/performing as Collector under sec.3(c); Rule 4 inquiry and report valid.
Compliance with Part VII, sec.39 consent valid; sec.4 and sec.6 notifications lawful.
No mala fides or non-application of mind established.
Acquisition for public purpose valid; prior use does not bar.
No additional hearing required beyond sec.5A before sec.6.

precedents_cited.relevance: Decision prompted Amendment Act XXXI of 1962 and Rules to overcome difficulties in company acquisitions.
Rejected argument that land used for one public purpose cannot be acquired for another public purpose.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act, 1894
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs notifications, inquiries, consent for company acquisitions, definition of Collector; compliance upheld.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition (Amendment) Act, XXXI of 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Retrospective amendment to overcome Arora case; enabled Rules.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition (Companies) Rules, 1963
statutes_cited.relevance: Requires Collector inquiry before sec.6; hearing Company; report to Government/Committee; inquiry held valid.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointment by office valid; rules terms same as Act unless repugnant.

outcome.summary: The Court rejected all contentions of the appellants, upheld the validity of the notifications under sections 4 and 6, the inquiry under Rule 4, consent under Part VII, found no mala fides or lack of public purpose, and no need for additional hearing; appeals dismissed.
outcome.costs: Appellants to pay costs of the appeals to the respondents. One hearing fee.

key_quotes.text: "The word specially has therefore reference to the special purpose of appointment and is not used to convey the sense of a special as against a general appointment."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets 'specially appointed' under sec.3(c), key to validity of Master's inquiry.

key_quotes.text: "The appellants failed to establish their allegation either as to mala fide or the non-application of mind by the State Government."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects core plea of mala fides.

key_quotes.text: "Neither sec. 5A nor any other provision of the Act lays down that a second opportunity has to be given before the issuance of section 6 notification."
key_quotes.speaker: court
